Topics include scientific computing; python; classical force fields and simulations; visualization and movie-making; quantum mechanics in drug discovery; molecular dynamics; solvation models; and several others.
title: Drug Discovery Computing Techniques

description: Fundamentals of medicinal chemistry covering diverse aspects of drug design, discovery, synthesis, and development. Molecular basis of drug action with an emphasis on the structure-to-function continuum.
title: Medicinal Chemistry

description: Introduces new paradigms in regenerative medicine particularly those that involve stem cells, and emerging molecular, nano- and micro-engineered tools for in vivo imaging that is critical for studying and monitoring regeneration.
title: Stem Cell Therapy

description: Introduces emerging, ground-breaking technologies in pharmaceutical sciences and medicine, including pharmacogenomics, genome editing, and stem cell and engineered T cell therapies. Explores these novel technologies with both their underlying theories and forward-thinking applications.
title: Emerging Technologies in Pharmaceutical Sciences and Medicine

description: Presentation and discussion of current problems and methods in teaching and research in pharmaceutical sciences.
title: Research Seminar

description: Supervised original research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty member.
title: Graduate Research

description: Limited to Teaching Assistants.
title: University Teaching

description: A selection of philosophical problems, concepts, and methods, e.g., free will, cause and substance, personal identity, the nature of philosophy itself. Materials fee.
title: Introduction to Philosophy

description: Introduction to the formal tools needed to comprehend and evaluate philosophical arguments and theoretical reasoning in general.
title: Puzzles and Paradoxes

description: A study of the nature of technology, its relation to human values, the philosophical assumptions in its development, and the philosophical implications of technology.
title: Technology and Society

description: Selected topics from the history of ethics, e.g., the nature of the good life and the moral justification of conduct.
title: Introduction to Ethics

description: Selected moral issues of current interest, e.g., abortion, sexual morality, euthanasia, capital punishment, reverse discrimination, civil disobedience, or violence.
title: Contemporary Moral Problems

description: An analysis of themes in phenomenology and existentialism and their philosophical origins, e.g., consciousness, self and other, freedom and individuality.
title: Introduction to Existentialism

description: Examination of the central philosophical themes developed by the pre-Socratics, Socrates, Plato, Aristotle, the Stoics, the Epicureans, and the Skeptics.
title: History of Ancient Philosophy

description: A study of some of the major theological and philosophical texts from the Medieval period.
title: History of Medieval Philosophy

description: A study of major developments in western philosophy from Descartes to Kant with readings from Descartes, Leibniz, Locke, Berkeley, Hume, and Kant.
title: History of Modern Philosophy

description: A study of recent philosophical developments in Anglo-American and Continental philosophy with readings from such figures as Russell, Moore, Wittgenstein, Quine, Heidegger, and Sartre.
title: History of Contemporary Philosophy

description: Examines the intersection of religion and philosophy from a standpoint that does not presuppose previous academic study of either.  Both Western and Eastern traditions and perspectives may be explored.
title: Philosophy and Religion

description: What constitutes a legal system? What does it mean for a society to have a system as a part of the social fabric. Examines the social status of law and its use as a tool for fashioning society.
title: Introduction to Law and Society

description: Introduction to analysis and reasoning. The concepts of argument, premise, and conclusion, validity and invalidity, consistency and inconsistency. Identifying and assessing premises and inferences. Deductive versus inductive reasoning, and introduction to the probability calculus. Evaluating definitions. Informal fallacies.
title: Critical Reasoning

description: An introduction to the symbolism and methods of the logic of statements, including evaluation of arguments by truth tables, the techniques of natural deduction, and semantic tableaux.
title: Introduction to Symbolic Logic

description: Philosophical questions concerning the foundations of scientific inference, e.g., the traditional problem of induction, the Goodman paradox, the concept of cause, Mill's method of inductive reasoning, probability calculus, different interpretations of probability, and their interaction in inductive reasoning.
title: Introduction to Inductive Logic

description: Lectures on selected topics at the lower-division level.
title: Special Topics in Philosophy

description: Discusses the origins of biological sex, dynamics of sexual selection, sex differences in humans, and the construction of gender in human societies. Seeks to understand the role social values play in the creation of science.
title: The Philosophy of Sex

description: Discussion of those aspects of writing of special importance in philosophy, e.g., philosophical terminology, techniques for evaluating arguments, philosophical definitions and theories. At least 4,000 words of assigned composition based on philosophical readings.
prerequisites: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
title: Writing Philosophy

description: A study of one or more of the problems of "first philosophy," e.g., substance, free will, causation, abstract entities, identity.
title: Introduction to Metaphysics

description: A study of one or more of the basic issues in epistemology, e.g., the role of perception in the acquisition of knowledge, the nature of evidence, the distinction between belief and knowledge, and the nature of truth and certainty.
title: Introduction to the Theory of Knowledge

description: A study of one or more of the basic issues in epistemology, e.g., the role of perception in the acquisition of knowledge, the nature of evidence, the distinction between belief and knowledge, and the nature of truth and certainty.
prerequisites: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
title: Introduction to the Theory of Knowledge

description: A study of one or more of the problems of contemporary moral philosophy, e.g., the nature of justice, liberalism versus conservatism, happiness and its relation to virtue and right conduct, the objectivity of moral standards.
title: Introduction to Moral Philosophy

description: Introduction to sentence logic, including truth tables and natural deduction; and to predicate logic, including semantics and natural deduction.
title: Introduction to Logic

description: An introduction to the basic working vocabulary of mathematical reasoning. Topics include sets, Boolean operations, ordered n-tuples, relations, functions, ordinal and cardinal numbers.
title: Elementary Set Theory

description: Introduction to formal syntax (proof theory) and semantics (model theory) for first-order logic, including the deduction, completeness, compactness, and Löewenheim-Skolem theorems.
title: Metalogic

description: Introduction to the formal theory of effective processes, including recursive functions, Turing machines, Church's thesis, and proofs of Göedel's incompleteness theorem for arithmetic, and Church's undecidability theorem for first-order logic.
title: Undecidability and Incompleteness

description: Selected topics in mathematical or philosophical logic.
title: Topics in Logic

description: Selected topics in induction, probability, and decision theory.
title: Topics in Induction, Probability, and Decision Theory

description: Selected topics from the writings of Plato and Aristotle, e.g., Aristotle's criticisms of Plato's metaphysics, ethics, or politics.
title: Topics in Ancient Philosophy

description: Studies of some of the major issues of concern to Medieval philosophers, e.g., universals, the nature and existence of God, faith, and reason.
title: Topics in Medieval Philosophy

description: Focuses on the works of central philosophical figures of modern Philosophy (e.g., Descartes, Leibniz, Hobbes, Locke, Hume, Kant) or on the treatment of one or more central philosophical problems by a number of these figures.
title: Topics in Modern Philosophy

description: Studies of some of the major figures after Kant (e.g., Hegel, Nietzsche, Marx, Kierkegaard), especially in German idealism and social thought.
title: Topics in Nineteenth-Century Philosophy

description: Review of central theories or figures in the history of analytic philosophy. Emphasis on writings of Frege, Russell, Schlick, Carnap, and Quine. Topics include the nature of meaning and truth, the synthetic/analytic distinction, and scientific knowledge.
title: Topics in History of Analytic Philosophy

description: Studies of some of the major figures (e.g., Husserl), movements (e.g., phenomenology, existentialism) in early twentieth-century continental European thought.
title: Topics in Continental Philosophy

description: Selected topics in the philosophies of Asia, e.g. Jainism, Buddhism, Yoga, Vedanta, Confucianism, Taoism, and Shinto.
title: Topics in Asian Philosophy

description: Examines central philosophical questions concerning our own fundamental nature and that of the world around us (e.g., causation and necessity, determination, free will, personal identity, the mind-body problem).
title: Topics in Metaphysics

description: One or more topics in the theory of knowledge, e.g., the nature of rational justification, of perceptual knowledge, of a priori knowledge.
title: Topics in the Theory of Knowledge

description: Analysis of epistemological issues concerning medical research and health care. Topics may include medical evidence, transmission of medical knowledge, medical expertise, the epistemology of medical disagreement, classification of illnesses, well-being, philosophy of pain, and medical decision making.
title: Medical Epistemology

description: Selected topics involving the concept of mind, e.g., the relation between mind and body, the self, personal identity, consciousness, the unconscious.
title: Topics in Philosophy of Mind

description: Critical examination of concepts involved in the theological literature, e.g., the nature and existence of God, miracles, the problem of evil, divine command theories in ethics.
title: Topics in Philosophy of Religion

description: Selected topics in ethics.
title: Topics in Moral Philosophy

description: Topics may include capital punishment, world hunger, obligations to future generations, environmental ethics, animal rights, economic justice, sexual morality, affirmative action, racism and sexism, or legalization of drugs.
title: Applied Ethics

description: Analysis of moral issues concerning health care. Topics may include just allocation of scarce medical resources, the doctor/patient relationship, genetic engineering, surrogate motherhood, abortion, euthanasia, or social policy concerning AIDS.
title: Medical Ethics

description: Selected topics in social and political philosophy, e.g., the functions of government, the justification of political authority, the nature of democracy, the varieties of liberty, and social justice. Readings from classical and contemporary sources.
title: Topics in Political and Social Philosophy

description: Selected topics concerning legal systems and the concept of law, e.g., the nature and purpose of law, the nature of authority, the relationship between law and morality, law and political-economic systems.
title: Topics in Philosophy of Law

description: Selected topics in contemporary philosophy of science, e.g., the status of theoretical entities, the confirmation of theories, the nature of scientific explanation.
title: Topics in Philosophy of Science

description: Selected topics in the philosophy of physics, e.g., the interpretation of quantum mechanics, the nature of spacetime, the problem of quantum field theories.
title: Topics in Philosophy of Physics

description: An examination of the foundations of the special theory of relativity, with emphasis on the geometry of Minkowski spacetime, and its relation to both Euclidean and non-Euclidean (hyperbolic) plane geometries.
title: Geometry and Spacetime

description: An examination of the standard von Neumann-Dirac formulation of quantum mechanics. The quantum measurement problem is discussed along with several proposed solutions, including GRW, many-worlds, man-minds, and Bohm's theory.
title: Philosophy of Quantum Mechanics

description: An examination of a cluster of interrelated issues concerning probability, determinism, logic, and the foundations of quantum mechanics.
title: Probability and Determinism

description: Philosophy of biology, e.g., scientific method in biology, the structure of evolutionary theory, teleology, ethics, and evolution. Course work includes one 4,000-word and four 1,000-word papers.
prerequisites: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
title: Writing/Philosophy of Biology

description: Selected topics in the philosophy of psychology, e.g., the nature of psychological explanation, reductionism, issues in cognitive, behavioral, and neuroscience.
title: Topics in Philosophy of Psychology

description: Selected topics in the philosophy of the social sciences, e.g., Is their goal to understand behavior or to predict and control it?; Are they normative and the natural sciences not?; Do they incorporate philosophical doctrines about language and mind?.
title: Topics in Philosophy of Social Science

description: Selected topics in the philosophy of language, e.g., the nature of meaning, mechanisms of reference, speech acts.
title: Topics in Philosophy of Language

description: Selected topics in the philosophy of logic, e.g., the nature of logical truth and our knowledge of it, the status of propositions, definite descriptions, and existential presuppositions.
title: Topics in Philosophy of Logic

description: Selected historical and contemporary topics in the philosophy of mathematics, e.g., mathematical truth and ontology, mathematical knowledge, the nature and role of proof, the workings of mathematics in application.
title: Topics in Philosophy of Mathematics

description: A study of the foundations of phenomenology in Husserl and its background in Bolzano, Frege, Brentano, Meinong, Kant, and Descartes.
title: Phenomenology

description: A study of such central existentialist thinkers as Heidegger and Sartre.
title: Existentialism

description: Examines how things in one’s social environment exist. Such things are compared and contrasted to others in what might be regarded as the given, natural environment. Topics discussed include natural kinds; artifacts; essentialism; constructivism; intentionality; agency.
title: Social Ontology

description: Social epistemology is specifically concerned with questions concerning knowledge and justification that arise in a social context. Topics discussed include testimony, experts, disagreement, group knowledge, feminist epistemology, legal epistemology, and epistemology of education.
title: Social Epistemology

description: Examines what it is that makes a life good (or bad) for the person who lives it. Topics include hedonism, desire-satisfaction theories of well-being (as well as other such theories), the notion of harm, the possibility of posthumous harm.
title: Well-Being

description: Philosophy of action is specifically concerned with questions concerning the nature of acting, and related phenomena such as intending, willing, trying, and trusting. It deals both with individual and group action and their moral and epistemological  underpinnings.
title: Philosophy of Action

description: Lectures on selected topics to be given by regular faculty and visiting faculty.
title: Special Topics in Philosophy

description: Independent study on a research topic supervised by a faculty member.
title: Directed Special Studies

description: Independent study on a research topic supervised by a faculty member, with the objective of preparing the Department of Philosophy honors paper.
title: Honors Directed Special Studies

description: Seminars on selected topics to be given by regular faculty and visiting faculty.
title: Special Topics in Philosophy

description: An examination of some standard works in the history of philosophy, value theory, metaphysics, or epistemology; required of all first-year Philosophy graduate students in the School of Humanities.
title: First-Year Seminar

description: The basic working vocabulary of mathematical reasoning. Topics include: sets, Boolean operations, ordered n-tuples, relations, functions, ordinal and cardinal numbers.
title: Set Theory

description: Formal syntax (proof theory) and semantics (model theory) for first-order logic, including the deduction, completeness, compactness, and Loewenheim-Skolem theorems.
title: Metalogic

description: Formal theory of effective processes, including recursive function, Turing machines, Church's thesis, proofs of Goedel's incompleteness theorem for arithmetics, and Church's undecidability for first-order logic.
title: Undecidability and Incompleteness

description: Studies in selected areas of logic. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Logic

description: Studies in selected areas of ancient philosophy.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Ancient Philosophy

description: Studies in selected areas of medieval philosophy.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Medieval Philosophy

description: Studies in selected areas of renaissance philosophy.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Renaissance Philosophy

description: Studies in selected areas of modern philosophy.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Modern Philosophy

description: Studies in selected areas of nineteenth-century philosophy.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Nineteenth-Century Philosophy

description: Studies in selected areas of analytic philosophy.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Analytic Philosophy

description: Studies in selected areas of continental philosophy. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Continental Philosophy

description: Studies in selected areas of contemporary philosophy. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Contemporary Philosophy

description: Studies in selected areas of metaphysics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Metaphysics

description: Studies in selected areas of epistemology. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Epistemology

description: Analysis of epistemological issues concerning medical research and healthcare. Topics may include medical evidence, transmission of medical knowledge in the doctor-patient interaction, medical expertise, epistemology of medical disagreement, classification of illness, well-being, philosophy of pain, or medical decision making.
title: Medical Epistemology

description: Studies in selected areas of mind and action. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Mind and Action

description: Studies in selected areas of ethics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Ethics

description: Studies in selected areas of political and social philosophy. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Political and Social Philosophy

description: Studies in selected areas of aesthetics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Aesthetics

description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Philosophy of Science

description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of physics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Philosophy of Physics

description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of biology. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Philosophy of Biology

description: Selected topics in the philosophy of psychology, e.g., the nature of psychological explanation, reductionism, issues in cognitive, behavioral, and neuroscience.
title: Topics in Philosophy of Psychology

description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy and social science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Philosophy of Social Science

description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of language. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Philosophy of Language

description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of logic. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Philosophy of Logic

description: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of mathematics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Philosophy of Mathematics

description: Studies in selected areas of existentialism and phenomenology. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Topics in Existentialism and Phenomenology

description: Independent research with Philosophy faculty.
title: Independent Study

description: Directed research with Philosophy faculty.
title: Directed Research

description: Limited to Teaching Assistants.
title: University Teaching

description: First in a series for students interested in becoming middle or high school teachers of mathematics or science. Students gain an understanding of effective, research-based teaching strategies. Includes supervised field experience in a K-12 classroom.
title: California Teach 1: Introduction to Science and Mathematics Teaching

description: Undergraduates identify, cultivate, and practice relevant soft skills applicable to careers in mathematics and science. The focus is on career readiness, how to market oneself to future employers, and what to expect from the professional world.
prerequisites: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
title: Skills Development

description: Second in a series for students interested in becoming middle or high school teachers of mathematics or science. Students gain an understanding of effective, research-based teaching strategies for grades 6-8. Includes supervised field experience in a middle school classroom.
title: California Teach 2: Middle School Science and Mathematics Teaching

description: Workshop in writing technical reports, journal articles, proposals. Oral presentations. Communicating with the public. May not be used in satisfaction of any School or departmental requirement.
prerequisites: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
title: Technical Writing and Communication Skills

description: Development of effective communication skills, oral and written presentations. Topics range from the art of creating keynote slides to strategically crafting a personal story, culminating in a live presentation to an invited audience.
title: Science Communication Skills

description: Provides the applied mathematics and problem solving/presentation skills necessary for success in an introductory physics sequence. Focuses on practical exercises in problem solving. Covers kinematics in one and two dimensions in detail. Additional topics include vectors, differentiation, and integration.
title: Introduction to Mathematical Methods for Physics

corequisites: MATH 2A or MATH 5A, or a score of 4 or higher on the AP Calculus AB exam, or a score of 3 or higher on the AP Calculus BC exam
description: Vectors; motion, force, and energy.
title: Basic Physics I

description: Fluids; heat; electricity and magnetism.
prerequisites: PHYSICS 3A or AP Physics C: Mechanics
title: Basic Physics II

corequisites: MATH 2B or MATH 5B, or a score of 4 or higher on the AP Calculus BC exam
description: Waves and sound; optics; quantum ideas; atomic and nuclear physics; relativity.
prerequisites: PHYSICS 3A or AP Physics C: Mechanics
title: Basic Physics III

description: Practical applications of electronics and classical physics to biology. Goals include skill to use oscilloscope and other basic instrumentation. Materials fee.
title: Basic Physics Laboratory

description: Practical applications of physics to medical imaging.  Topics include optics, radioactivity, and acoustics. Materials fee.
title: Basic Physics Laboratory

corequisites: MATH 2B or AP CALCULUS BC, min score = 4
description: Topics include force, energy, momentum, rotation, and gravity.
prerequisites: (CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C or CHEM M3C) or CHEM M2C) or AP Physics C: Mechanics or AP Physics C: Electricity
Magnetism or SAT Mathematics or ACT Mathematics
title: Classical Physics

description: Electricity and magnetism.
title: Classical Physics

description: Fluids; oscillations; waves; and optics.
title: Classical Physics

description: Experiments related to lecture topics in Physics 7C. Materials fee.
title: Classical Physics Laboratory

description: Electricity and magnetism.
title: Classical Physics Laboratory

description: An introduction to fundamental physics principles, the scientific process, and the mathematical language of science, used to analyze topics drawn from superheroes, science fiction works, and current science news to distinguish science fiction and science fact.
title: Science Fiction and Science Fact

description: The physics of society’s energy production and consumption, and of their influences on the environment. Topics include fossil and renewable energy resources; nuclear power; prospects for a hydrogen economy; efficient and environmentally benign transportation; efficient home and commercial energy usage.
title: Energy and the Environment

description: Introduces basic physical principles underlying generation and properties of music, including basic properties of sound waves, musical scales and temperament, musical instruments, and acoustics of music halls.  No mathematics background required, but high school algebra is recommended.
title: Physics of Music

description: Introduces basic physical principles behind motion. Examples are drawn from a range of athletic endeavors (such as ice skating, baseball, diving, and dance). No mathematics background required, but high school algebra is recommended.
title: Physics of Athletics

description: Survey of the physical basis of modern technology, with an emphasis on electronics and materials. Topics include power generation and distribution, communication (radio, TV, telephone, computers, tape recorders, CD players), imaging (optics, x-rays, MRI), and modern materials (alloys, semiconductors, superconductors).
title: How Things Work

description: Introduces non-science majors to physics, examining important breakthroughs and controversies. Potential topics: Einstein's Relativity; Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle; black holes; extra-dimensions; antimatter. Case studies illustrate the essential nature of scientific review and independent confirmation of results. No mathematics background required.
title: Great Ideas of Physics

description: History of astronomy. Underlying physics. Objects in the solar system and how they are studied. Properties of stars: their formation, structure, and evolution. Pulsars and black holes. Galaxies and quasars.
title: Introduction to Astronomy

description: An overview of the origin, evolution, and ultimate fate of the Universe. Galaxies and dark matter. The Big Bang and dark energy.  Ancient world models.
title: Cosmology: Humanity's Place in the Universe

description: Space exploration. Human missions to the moon, Mars, and beyond. Space stations, observatories, and deep-space probes. Robots and drones on distant worlds. Propulsion mechanisms, rockets, space flight, and the dangers of solar radiation.
title: Space Science

description: An overview of the scientific quest to discover life elsewhere in the universe. Topics include the origin of life on Earth, Mars, extra-solar planets, interstellar travel, and extra-terrestrial intelligence.
title: Life in the Universe

description: Topics addressed vary each quarter. Past topics have included physics and music, Newton, planetary science. Lectures on areas of special interest in physics used to introduce students to scientific method, fundamental laws of science, qualitative and quantitative analysis of data.
title: Special Topics in Physics

description: Introduction to math methods for upper-division physics. Taylor and Fourier series; complex algebra; ordinary differential equations; matrices, tensors and vector spaces; eigensystems; orthogonal coordinates; vector calculus and fields. Symbolic computation with Mathematica is incorporated through-out.
title: Introductory Mathematical Physics

description: Wave-particle duality; quantum mechanics; special relativity; statistical mechanics.
title: Modern Physics

description: Optics: lenses, mirrors, polarization, lasers, optical fibers, interference, spectra. Materials fee.
title: Fundamentals of Experimental Physics

description: Circuits: oscilloscope, meters, DC and AC circuits. Materials fee.
title: Fundamentals of Experimental Physics

description: Data analysis: random and systematic errors, curve fitting; nuclear counting; quantum experiments. Error analysis: random and systematic errors, curve fitting, nuclear counting, and quantum experiments. Materials fee.
title: Fundamentals of Experimental Physics

description: Introduction to structured programming; in-depth training in python. Elementary numerical methods applied to physics problems.
title: Introduction to Programming and Numerical Analysis

description: Introduction to thermodynamics and systems of many particles. Topics include first and second laws of thermodynamics, ideal gas laws, kinetic theory, heat engines and refrigerators, thermodynamic potentials, phase transitions, dilute solutions, chemical equilibrium, and basic statistical distributions.
title: Thermal Physics

description: Wave-particle duality; Schrödinger equation; angular momentum.
title: Modern Physics for Majors

description: Atomic transitions; molecules; solids; nuclei; elementary particles; cosmological models.
title: Modern Physics for Majors

description: Introduction to fundamental topics in astrophysics, including stellar structure and evolution; stellar remnants; detection and characterization of exoplanets; physics of interstellar gas and star-forming regions.
title: Introduction to Astrophysics

description: Introduction to science in 1914 and WWI. Participants in groups of two or three will pick a preferred science; find out what happened to it during and after the war; write reports and present what they learned.
title: Impact of World War I on Science

description: A series of fundamental and applied scientific problems of social relevance. Possible topics include Newton's Law, calculus, earthquake physics, and radiation.
title: The Idiom and Practice of Science

description: Designed to introduce undergraduate students to current topics in physics. Focus is discussion of selected readings on current research issues.
title: Current Topics in Physics

description: Mathematical and numerical analysis using Mathematica and C programming, as applied to problems in physical science.
title: Computational Methods

description: Introduces modern practical laboratory techniques for developing data interface devices, acquiring and analyzing data, and writing up results in manuscript format. Experiments include interfacing with instruments through software and hardware development, PID controller, Fourier analysis, and lock-in amplifier.
title: Advanced Data Acquisition, Analysis, and Scientific Writing

description: One-dimensional motion and oscillations; three-dimensional motion, non-inertial coordinates, conservation laws, and Lagrangian and Hamiltonian dynamics; rigid body motion and relativity.
title: Classical Mechanics

description: One-dimensional motion and oscillations; three-dimensional motion, non-inertial coordinates, conservation laws, and Lagrangian and Hamiltonian dynamics; rigid body motion and relativity.
title: Classical Mechanics

description: Electric, magnetic, and gravitational fields and potentials; electrodynamics; mechanical and electromagnetic waves and radiation.
title: Electromagnetic Theory

description: Electric, magnetic, and gravitational fields and potentials; electrodynamics; mechanical and electromagnetic waves and radiation.
title: Electromagnetic Theory

description: Inadequacy of classical physics; time independent and time dependent Schrodinger equation; systems in one, two, and three dimensions; matrices; Hermitian operators; symmetries; angular momentum; perturbation theory; scattering theory; applications to atomic structure; emphasis on phenomenology.
title: Quantum Physics

description: Inadequacy of classical physics; time independent and time dependent Schrodinger equation; systems in one, two, and three dimensions; matrices; Hermitian operators; symmetries; angular momentum; perturbation theory; scattering theory; applications to atomic structure; emphasis on phenomenology.
title: Quantum Physics

description: Inadequacy of classical physics; time independent and time dependent Schrodinger equation; systems in one, two, and three dimensions; matrices; Hermitian operators; symmetries; angular momentum; perturbation theory; scattering theory; applications to atomic structure; emphasis on phenomenology.
title: Quantum Physics

description: Microscopic theory of temperature, heat, and entropy; kinetic theory; multicomponent systems; quantum statistics.
title: Statistical Physics

description: Introduces students to both special and general relativity; includes the formalism of four-vectors, equivalence principle, curved space-time, and modern issues with black holes.
title: Relativity and Black Holes

description: Applications of modern semiconductor devices to physical instrumentation. Characteristics of semiconductor devices, integrated circuits, analog and digital circuits. Materials fee.
title: Electronics for Scientists

description: Experiments in atomic, condensed matter, nuclear, particle, and plasma physics. Introduction to instrumentation and a first experience in the research laboratory.
title: Advanced Laboratory

description: Complex variables; Legendre and Bessel functions; complete sets of orthogonal functions; partial differential equations; integral equations; calculus of variations; coordinate transformations; special functions and series.
title: Mathematical Physics

description: Complex variables; Legendre and Bessel functions; complete sets of orthogonal functions; partial differential equations; integral equations; calculus of variations; coordinate transformations; special functions and series.
title: Mathematical Physics

description: Phenomena of solids and their interpretation in terms of quantum theory.
title: Introduction to Condensed Matter Physics

description: Focuses on the practical aspects of optics and optical engineering, starting at the fundamentals. Topics include geometrical optics, ray tracing, polarization optics, interferometers, and diffractive optics.
title: Physical and Geometrical Optics

description: Basic concepts, orbits, kinetic and fluid equations, Coulomb collisions, fluctuations, scattering, radiation.
title: Plasma Physics

description: Experimental techniques and theoretical concepts of high-energy phenomena: accelerators and detectors; classification of particles and interactions; particle properties; symmetries and mass multiplets; production and decay mechanisms.
title: Introduction to Particle Physics

description: Solution of the differential equations governing the expansion of the Universe. Observational determinations of the parameters governing the expansion. Big Bang inflation, primordial nucleosynthesis, and cosmic microwave background. Dark matter, dark energy, and large-scale structure of the Universe.
title: Introduction to Cosmology

description: Introduction to the solar neighborhood, Milky Way, and other galaxies. Interstellar medium. Star formation. Stellar populations. Evolution of spiral, elliptical, and irregular galaxies. Supermassive black holes, quasars, and active galaxies. Galaxies as probes of the expansion rate of the Universe.
title: Astrophysics of Galaxies

description: Telescopes and astronomical observations, imaging with CCD detectors and image processing techniques. Photometry and spectroscopy of stars, galaxies, and quasars. Advanced imaging techniques such as deconvolution, adaptive optics, and interferometry.
title: Observational Astrophysics

description: Stars: their structure and evolution; physical state of the interior; the Hertzprung- Russell diagram, stellar classification, and physical principles responsible for the classification; star formation; nuclear burning; giant and dwarf stars; neutron stars and black holes.
title: Stellar Astrophysics

description: Production of radiation by high-energy particles, white dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes. Evolution of galactic nuclei, radio galaxies, quasars, and pulsars.  Cosmic rays and the cosmic background radiation.
title: High-Energy Astrophysics

description: Physical concepts and experimental and computational techniques used to study the structure and function of biological molecules and molecular machines with examples from enzyme action, protein folding, molecular motors, photobiology, chemotaxis, and vision.
title: Biophysics of Molecules and Molecular Machines

description: Physical concepts and experimental and computational techniques used to study the structure and function of biological molecules and molecular machines with examples from enzyme action, protein folding, molecular motors, photobiology, chemotaxis, and vision.
title: Biophysics of Molecules and Molecular Machines

description: Ionizing radiation, planar and tomographic radiographic and nuclear imaging, magnetism, NMR, MRI imaging.
title: Techniques in Medical Imaging I: X-ray, Nuclear, and NMR Imaging

description: Sound and ultrasound, ultrasonic imaging, physiological electromagnetism, EEG, MEG, ECG, MCG, optical properties of tissues, fluorescence and bioluminescence, MR impedance imaging, MR spectroscopy, electron spin resonance and ESR imaging.
title: Techniques in Medical Imaging II: Ultrasound, Electrophysiological, Optical

description: Current topics in physics.  Includes topics from nano-science, biological sciences, astrophysics, and the common use of estimation across subdisciplines within physics.
title: Special Topics in Physics and Astronomy

description: Students develop and perform physics assemblies at neighboring public schools.
title: Field Experience in Physics Education

description: Formalizes the already existing free tutoring for the lower-division physics courses that is provided by the Society of Physics Students (SPS). Includes instructions on tutoring techniques.
title: Tutoring in Physics

description: Explores tools of inquiry for developing and implementing science research projects.  Students undertake independent projects requiring data collection, analysis, and modeling, and the organization and presentation of results.  Additional topics include ethical issues and role of scientific literature.
title: Research Methods

description: Students learn the fundamentals of communicating about research. Topics include preparing abstracts, proposals, and literature reviews. Provides preparation for presentation of independent research projects in PHYSICS 121 and PHYSICS 196.
title: Research Communication for Physics Majors

description: Independent research under the guidance of a Physics faculty member.
title: Undergraduate Research

description: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students’ research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.
title: Thesis in Physics I

description: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students’ research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.
title: Thesis in Physics II

description: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students’ research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.
title: Thesis in Physics III

description: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students’ research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.
title: Honors Thesis in Physics I

description: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students’ research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.
title: Honors Thesis in Physics II

description: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students’ research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.
title: Honors Thesis in Physics III

description: Readings in selected areas of Physics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Readings on Special Topics

description: Introduces students to a variety of practical laboratory techniques, including lock-in, boxcar, coincidence counting, noise filtering, PID control, properties of common transducers, computer interfacing to instruments, vacuum technology, laboratory safety, basic mechanical design, and shop skills. Materials fee.
title: Advanced Data Acquisition and Analysis

description: Introduction to fundamental concepts in molecular structure and reactivity: theory of bonding, valence and molecular orbitals; structure and reactivity in inorganic chemistry; elements in molecular group theory; nomenclature in organic chemistry; and survey of macromolecules.
title: Applied Physical Chemistry

description: Applications of mathematics to physical and chemical problems. Calculus of special functions, complex variables and vectors; linear vector spaces and eigenvalue problems. Differential equations.
title: Math Methods

description: Variational principles, Lagrange's equations; applications to two body problems, small oscillation theory, and other phenomena. Hamilton's equations. Hamilton-Jacobi theory. Canonical transformations.
title: Classical Mechanics

description: Complex variables and integration; ordinary and partial differential equations; the eigenvalue problem.
title: Mathematical Physics

description: Electrostatics; magnetostatics; relativity; classical electron theory; fields in vacuum and matter; retardation; radiation and absorption; dispersion; propagation of light; diffraction; geometric optics; theories of the electric and magnetic properties of materials; scattering.
title: Electromagnetic Theory

description: Electrostatics; magnetostatics; relativity; classical electron theory; fields in vacuum and matter; retardation; radiation and absorption; dispersion; propagation of light; diffraction; geometric optics; theories of the electric and magnetic properties of materials; scattering.
title: Electromagnetic Theory

description: Maxwell-Boltzmann, Bose-Einstein, Fermi-Dirac statistics; ideal and imperfect gases; thermodynamic properties of solids; transport theory.
title: Statistical Physics

description: Application of field theory methods, perturbative and non-perturbative, to many particle systems; second quantization, Feynman diagrams, linear response theory, and functional integral methods applied to the ground state and at finite temperature.
title: Many Body Theory

description: Foundations; Dirac notation; basic operators and their eigenstates; perturbation theory; spin.
title: Quantum Mechanics

description: Atomic physics; scattering theory, formal collision theory; semi-classical radiation theory; many body systems.
title: Quantum Mechanics

description: Applications of modern semiconductor devices to physical instrumentation. Characteristics of semiconductor devices, integrated circuits, analog and digital circuits.
title: Electronics for Scientists

description: Introduction to the continuum limit and stress and strain tensors. Hydrodynamics of perfect fluids; two-dimensional problems, motion of incompressible viscous fluids, Navier Stokes equations. Basic elasticity theory. Description of viscoelastic materials. Introduction to nonlinear behavior instabilities.
title: Continuum Mechanics

description: Introduction to theory and practice of modern numerical methods. Techniques are drawn from topics such as solution of differential equations, Monte Carlo methods, Fast Fourier transforms, and evaluation of special functions.
title: Numerical Methods

description: Maxwell’s equations, electrodynamics, electromagnetic waves and radiation, wave propagation in media, interference and quantum optics, coherent and incoherent radiation, with practical applications in interferometry, lasers, waveguides, and optical instrumentation.
title: Electromagnetism

description: Mathematical and numerical analysis using Mathematica and C programming, as applied to problems in physical science.
title: Computational Methods

description: Physical concepts and experimental and computational techniques used to study the structure and function of biological molecules and molecular machines with examples from enzyme action, protein folding, molecular motors, photobiology, chemotaxis, and vision.
title: Biophysics of Molecules and Molecular Machines

description: Physical concepts and experimental and computational techniques used to study the structure and function of biological molecules and molecular machines with examples from enzyme action, protein folding, molecular motors, photobiology, chemotaxis, and vision.
title: Biophysics of Molecules and Molecular Machines

description: Linear systems, probability and random processes, image processing, projecting imaging, tomographic imaging.
title: Principles of Imaging

description: Ionizing radiation, planar and tomographic radiographic and nuclear imaging, magnetism, NMR, MRI imaging.
title: Techniques in Medical Imaging I: X-ray, Nuclear, and NMR Imaging

description: Sound and ultrasound, ultrasonic imaging, physiological electromagnetism, EEG, MEG, ECG, MCG, optical properties of tissues, fluorescence and bioluminescence, MR impedance imaging, MR spectroscopy, electron spin resonance and ESR imaging.
title: Techniques in Medical Imaging II: Ultrasound, Electrophysiological, Optical

description: Overview of Standard Model theory and phenomenology. Electromagnetic, strong and weak forces, quark model, interactions with matter, particle detectors and accelerators.
title: Elementary Particle Physics

description: SU(3)xSU(2)xU(1) model of strong, weak, and electromagnetic interactions. K-meson system and CP violation, neutrino masses and mixing, grand-unified theories, supersymmetry, introduction to cosmology and its connection to particle physics.
title: Advanced Elementary Particle Physics

description: SU(3)xSU(2)xU(1) model of strong, weak, and electromagnetic interactions. K-meson system and CP violation, neutrino masses and mixing, grand-unified theories, supersymmetry, introduction to cosmology and its connection to particle physics.
title: Advanced Elementary Particle Physics

description: Canonical quantization, scalar field theory, Feynman diagrams, tree-level quantum electrodynamics.
title: Quantum Field Theory

description: Pathintegral techniques, loop diagrams, regularization and renormalization, anomalies.
title: Advanced Quantum Field Theory

description: Bonding in solids; crystal symmetry and group theory, elastic properties of crystals; lattice vibrations, interaction of radiation with matter; cohesion of solids; the electron gas; electron energy bands in solids; ferromagnetism; transport theory; semiconductors and superconductors; many-body perturbation theory.
title: Condensed Matter Physics

description: Bonding in solids; crystal symmetry and group theory, elastic properties of crystals; lattice vibrations, interaction of radiation with matter; cohesion of solids; the electron gas; electron energy bands in solids; ferromagnetism; transport theory; semiconductors and superconductors; many-body perturbation theory.
title: Condensed Matter Physics

description: Bonding in solids; crystal symmetry and group theory, elastic properties of crystals; lattice vibrations, interaction of radiation with matter; cohesion of solids; the electron gas; electron energy bands in solids; ferromagnetism; transport theory; semiconductors and superconductors; many-body perturbation theory.
title: Condensed Matter Physics

description: Basic concepts, orbits, kinetic and fluid equations, Coulomb collisions, fluctuations, scattering, radiation.
title: Plasma Physics

description: Magnetic confinement, MHD equilibrium and stability, collisional transport.
title: Plasma Physics

description: Linear waves and instabilities, uniform un-magnetized and magnetized plasmas, non-uniform plasmas.
title: Plasma Physics

description: The morphology, kinematics, and evolution of our Milky Way and other galaxies.  Topics include stellar formation and stellar evolution, end states of stars (supernovae, neutron stars), the distribution of stars, interstellar gas and mass in galaxies. The Local Group.
title: Galactic Astrophysics

description: An introduction to modern cosmology set within the context of general relativity.  Topics include the expansion history of the Universe, inflation, the cosmic microwave background, density fluctuations, structure formation, dark matter, dark energy, and gravitational lensing.
title: Cosmology

description: Exploration of radiation mechanisms (electron scattering, synchrotron emission, collisional excitation, and more) and radiative transfer through matter including absorption and emission. Includes such observational astrophysics topics as spectroscopic study of atoms and nuclei, X-rays, and cosmic rays.
title: Radiative Processes in Astrophysics

description: Formation, evolution, and habitability of planetary systems. Observational and theoretical study of the origin and evolution of the Solar System, present day dynamical state of the Solar System (asteroids, Kuiper Belt Objects, Oort cloud), planetary atmospheres, processes governing planetary climate.
title: Solar System and Extrasolar Planets

description: Physics of stellar interiors and equations of stellar structure. Stellar atmospheres and absorption processes. Introduction to stellar winds. Thermonuclear reactions, nucleosynthesis, and solar neutrinos. Binary stars and mass accretion. White dwarfs, supernovae, neutron stars, and black holes.
title: Stellar Astrophysics

description: The physics and phenomenology of galaxies; star formation, interstellar medium, and intergalactic medium.  Galaxy structure and dynamics.  Galaxy evolution, stellar populations, and scaling relations; the relationship between galaxy properties and environment.  Galaxy clusters and active galactic nuclei.
title: Extragalactic Astrophysics

description: Includes a thorough quantum treatment of the generation of perturbations during inflation and various topics related to kinetic theory in an expanding Universe.  Other topics include the astrophysics and cosmology of weakly interacting particles.
title: Early Universe Physics

description: Introduction to topics in astrophysics including measurement of stellar properties, stellar structure and evolution, stellar remnants and supernovae, the interstellar medium, exoplanets, gravitational lensing, galactic structure, extragalactic distance measurements, and the expanding universe.
title: Astro Fundamentals

description: Outlines and emphasizes a subarea of astrophysics that is undergoing rapid development.
title: Special Topics in Astrophysics

description: Current topics in particle non-accelerator-based research fields.
title: Special Topics in Particle Physics

description: Outlines and emphasizes a subarea of condensed matter physics that is undergoing rapid development.
title: Special Topics in Condensed Matter Physics

description: Outlines and emphasizes a subarea of plasma physics that is undergoing rapid development.
title: Special Topics in Plasma Physics

description: Fundamentals of effectively communicating research through written and oral platforms. Topics include writing compelling proposals and journal articles for peer review, and the development of engaging oral presentations of science results and significance to a wide range of audiences.
title: Physics and Astronomy Communications Skills

description: An introduction to Einstein’s theory of gravitation. Tensor analysis, Einstein’s field equations, astronomical tests of Einstein’s theory, gravitational waves.
title: General Relativity

description: Seminar designed to acquaint students with recent advances in solid state physics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy (both faculty and graduate students), other UCI departments, and other institutions.
title: Seminar in Condensed Matter Physics

description: Seminar designed to acquaint students with recent advances in solid state physics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy (both faculty and graduate students), other UCI departments, and other institutions.
title: Seminar in Condensed Matter Physics

description: Seminar designed to acquaint students with recent advances in solid state physics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy (both faculty and graduate students), other UCI departments, and other institutions.
title: Seminar in Condensed Matter Physics

description: Advanced topics in plasma physics:  wave propagation, nonlinear effects, kinetic theory and turbulence, stability problems, transport coefficients, containment, and diagnostics. Applications to controlled fusion and astrophysics.
title: Seminar in Plasma Physics

description: Advanced topics in plasma physics:  wave propagation, nonlinear effects, kinetic theory and turbulence, stability problems, transport coefficients, containment, and diagnostics. Applications to controlled fusion and astrophysics.
title: Seminar in Plasma Physics

description: Advanced topics in plasma physics:  wave propagation, nonlinear effects, kinetic theory and turbulence, stability problems, transport coefficients, containment, and diagnostics. Applications to controlled fusion and astrophysics.
title: Seminar in Plasma Physics

description: Discussion of advanced topics and reports of current research results in theoretical and experimental particle physics and cosmic rays.
title: Seminar in Particle Physics

description: Discussion of advanced topics and reports of current research results in theoretical and experimental particle physics and cosmic rays.
title: Seminar in Particle Physics

description: Discussion of advanced topics and reports of current research results in theoretical and experimental particle physics and cosmic rays.
title: Seminar in Particle Physics

description: Acquaints students with current research in astrophysics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy and from other institutions.
title: Seminar in Astrophysics

description: Acquaints students with current research in astrophysics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy and from other institutions.
title: Seminar in Astrophysics

description: Acquaints students with current research in astrophysics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy and from other institutions.
title: Seminar in Astrophysics

description: The subjects covered vary from year to year.  Connection between fundamental principles and implementations in practice in science, industry, and technology.
title: Current Topics in Chemical, Applied, and Materials Physics

description: Presentation and discussion of current research and theory in particle physics.  Lectures given by staff and students.
title: Current Problems in Particle Physics

description: Presentation and discussion of current research and theory in particle physics.  Lectures given by staff and students.
title: Current Problems in Particle Physics

description: A research and journal club seminar that covers topics on bacteria and phage using approaches and principles from biology, engineering, and physics.
title: Seminar in Systems Microbiology Research

description: Techniques for effective teaching.  Covers active listening and student engagement, problem-solving skills, peer instruction and collaborative learning, and evaluation.  Required of all new Teaching Assistants.
title: Seminar in Teaching Physics

description: Development of effective communication skills, oral and written presentations, through examples and practice.
title: Technical Communication Skills

description: Detailed discussion of research problems of current interest in the Department.  Format, content, and frequency of the course are variable.
title: Research Seminar

description: With the approval of a faculty member, a student may pursue a research program in experimental physics.  Typical areas include astrophysics, condensed matter physics, elementary particle physics, and plasma physics.
title: Experimental Research

description: With approval of a faculty member, a student may pursue a research program in theoretical physics. Typical areas include astrophysics, condensed matter physics, elementary particle physics, and plasma physics.
title: Theoretical Research

description: Seminar held each week, in which a current research topic is explored. Frequently, off-campus researchers are invited to present the seminar, and on occasion a faculty member or researcher from the Department will speak.
title: Physics Colloquium

description: With special consent from a faculty member who will agree to supervise the program, a student may receive course credit for individual study of some area of physics.
title: Reading of Special Topic

description: Required of and limited to teaching assistants of undergraduate laboratory courses. Designed to teach the  necessary skills required of teaching assistants for these courses.
title: Laboratory Teaching

description: Required of and limited to Teaching Assistants.
title: University Teaching

description: Individual research directed toward doctoral dissertation and supervised by a particular professor.
title: Research in Physiology and Biophysics

description: Independent research within the laboratories of graduate training faculty in the Department of Physiology and Biophysics for first-year Ph.D. students.
title: Research in Physiology and Biophysics for First-Year Students

description: Introduction to research in physiology and related sciences. Concentrates on techniques emphasized in the various laboratories of the Department of Physiology and Biophysics.
title: Introduction to Physiology Research

description: Principles of crystallography; introduction to time-resolved absorption and fluorescence spectroscopy; the concepts of kinetic order and kinetic rate theory.
title: Concepts of Biophysics

description: Basic principles of electricity; properties and use of discrete components and integrated circuits; circuit analysis and design. Intended for advanced students in the life sciences.
title: Electronics for Biologists

description: Vertebrate physiology with emphasis on humans and on the relationship between the function of normal tissues and the processes of disease. Fundamental principles of physiology and the interrelationships which control organ function.
title: Introduction to Medical Physiology

description: Vertebrate physiology with emphasis on humans and on the relationship between the function of normal tissues and the processes of disease. Fundamental principles of physiology and the interrelationships which control organ function.
title: Introduction to Medical Physiology

description: One of the cornerstones of the MS1 Molecular Basis of Medicine block. Includes temporal coordination of lecture material, regular course director meetings, and combined exams with PHYSIO 544: Medical Immunology.
title: Medical Immunology

description: Provides an introduction to immunology, but focuses on providing in-depth analysis of selected topics within the broader field of immunology, including relevant research techniques, while improving critical thinking skills.
title: Integrative Immunology

description: Discusses how ion channels work (molecular/structural biophysics level) and what ion channels do in diverse cell types (cell physiology level).
title: The Physiology of Ion Channels

description: Introduces students to concepts and methods of proteomics including protein identification, expression proteomics, and protein-protein interactions.
title: Introduction to Proteomics

description: Introduces the anatomic and physiological basis of vertebrate vision and disease states in which the structure and function of the eye is disrupted with emphasis on current and developing research areas.
title: Eye: Health and Disease

description: Contemporary research problems in physiology. Students review research articles in current literature and present ideas contained therein, focusing on groundbreaking discoveries and methodologies. Students present results of their own research and attend presentations given by other students and departmental researchers.
title: Topics in Physiology

description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.
title: Scientific Communication

description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.
title: Scientific Communication

description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.
title: Scientific Communication

description: Preparation and completion of the dissertation required for the Ph.D.
title: Dissertation in Physiology and Biophysics

description: Explores different approaches to public policy analysis, the diverse conceptions of the goals and objectives that should be served by policy, and the appropriate role of the policy analyst. Policy consequences are traced to indirect and subtle incentives and disincentives.
title: Public Policy

description: Introduction to the variety of statistical applications in the social sciences.  Descriptive statistics.  Measures of central tendency and dispersion.  Percentile ranks.  Standardization and normal approximation.  Basic probability theory focuses on application to statistical inference and binomial distribution.  Laboratory required.
title: Probability and Statistics in Political Science I

description: Introduction to statistical inference, sampling distribution, standard error.  Hypothesis tests for proportions and means. Inferential techniques for nominal variables including chi-square, study measures of strengths, significance of relationships between variables, assumptions, data requirements, and types of error in significance tests.
title: Probability and Statistics in Political Science II

description: Focus on correlation, regression, and control for effects of variables.  One-way and two-way factorial analysis of variance.  A priori and a posteriori comparisons.  Introduction to repeated measures design and non-parametric statistics. Discusses use of statistics in newspapers and popular magazines.
title: Probability and Statistics in Political Science III

description: Presents various modes of understanding politics. Emphasis on basic approaches to political analysis, their uses in constructing theories, and their application to particular national political systems.
title: Introduction to Political Science: Political Analysis

description: Introduction to political behavior of individuals and groups within national systems. Three questions addressed: How do individuals come to understand the political world? How do individuals behave within this world? How do groups and individuals engage in the political process.
title: Introduction to Political Science: Micropolitics

description: Introduction to American political processes and institutions. Topics include elections, political participation, parties, interest groups, the Presidency, Congress, the bureaucracy, and the judiciary.
title: Introduction to American Government

description: Types of questions:  What is politics?  What are the theoretical and philosophical bases for different types of political arrangements?  How do these perspectives get translated into reality?  Among others, the works of Rousseau, Locke, Mill, and Marx are read.
title: Introduction to Political Theory

description: Focuses on racial, ethnic, and gender diversity, multiculturalism, and their impact on our social and political ideals. Traces the sources of ideas about difference, equality, and toleration, and examines tensions that occur when forms of identity conflict with one another.
title: Dilemmas of Diversity

description: Analysis of political relations between and among nations with emphasis on explanations of conflict and cooperation. The role of ideologies and their relation to international problems are also examined.
title: Introduction to International Relations

description: An overview of the major political ideologies shaping the current world order and global conflict. Topics include liberalism, democracy, nationalism, capitalism, communism, socialism, fascism, neoliberalism, clash of civilizations, sectarian violence, populist nationalism, and de-globalization.
title: Global Political Ideologies

description: Historical development of civil, political rights and the rise of human rights in international law. Explores role, and limitations, of the UN, ICJ, and ICC in global governance. Reconceptualizing democracy and political representation in a postnational 21st century.
title: Human Rights and Global Governance

description: Studies in selected areas of international relations. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Lower-Division Special Topics in International Relations

description: Introduces comparative politics. Compares political systems in a variety of countries. Includes elections, parties, parliaments, presidents, protest movements, and other aspects of national politics. Addresses how to make meaningful comparisons across countries.
title: Introduction to Politics Around the World

description: Examines major theories that attempt to explain the roles of race and ethnicity in U.S. politics.
title: Introduction to Race and Ethnicity in Political Science

description: An introduction to the study of judicial politics.  Questions include:  what is law?; what is a court?; who are the judges? Analysis of a wide range of judicial decisions illustrates the political importance of courts in the U.S. and elsewhere.
title: Introduction to Law

description: Studies in selected areas of law. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Lower-Division Special Topics in Law

description: Emerging issues of human security in the globalized world, including personal human security, physical integrity, human trafficking, global climate change, food. Challenges of these complex human security problems for a multi-scalar system (international, national, local).
title: Globalization and Human Security

description: Theories concerning sources of public opinion, processes by which it is altered, organization of citizens’ belief systems, and role of public opinion in government policy. Students analyze survey data as a research project.
title: Public Opinion

description: Presents a comprehensive survey of the American presidency and considers the question of political power.
title: The American Presidency

description: Examines how voters evaluate political parties, candidates, and issues in electoral campaigns to reach their decisions. Numerous controversies concerning the degree of issue voting, sophistication of candidate evaluations, and the decline of political parties are discussed.
title: U

description: Reviews the actions and character of presidents from Harry Truman through Bill Clinton.  Each week a different president is examined from a variety of perspectives.  Students are expected to write a substantial original research paper.
title: Presidents Since World War II

description: Focuses on the development and implementation of public policy in the United States. Lectures cover theoretical models of the policy process as well as significant problems facing contemporary American decision-makers.
title: American Public Policy

description: Imagines how White House staffers can help presidents with clear, focused, and effective writing. Through a variety of formats, students study, hone, and practice writing skills that will prove useful- in and out of the White House.
title: Writing for the President of the United States

description: Explores the politics of urban and suburban America, including the policy making process; the exercise of political power; local politics, federalism and the problems of metropolitanism; and major policy problems facing urban areas.
title: American Metropolitan Politics

description: Examines the structure and function of California government, traces historical development of political power, with constantly changing casts of power-brokers and seekers. Explores California exceptionalism and the roles played by the electorate, legislature, executive, and organized interests in policy making.
title: California Politics

description: Examines the structure and function of California government, traces historical development of political power, with constantly changing casts of power-brokers and seekers. Explores California exceptionalism and the roles played by the electorate, legislature, executive, and organized interests in policy making.
prerequisites: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division writing requirement
title: California Politics

description: Deals with classical theories of representation: issues of racial and political representation in U.S. legislatures and city councils; proportional representation models; and comparative election systems.
prerequisites: SOC SCI 3A or SOC SCI 10A or SOC SCI 10B
title: Representation

description: Examines the Civil Rights, Black Power, and women’s movements in relationship to the Asian American movement. Uses social movement theories to illuminate the cases, and the cases to critique and revise the theories.
title: The Politics of Protest

description: Comparing the political issues facing Latino groups by examining their migration histories, voting behavior, nonelectoral participation, and policy issues.  Latino issues are examined on the national, state, and local levels, including formal representation, immigration, affirmative action, and language policy.
title: Latinos in U

description: Examines the political experiences of Blacks, Latinos, and Asian Americans in the United States from roughly 1950 to the present. Focuses on how each group has pursued political empowerment via both conventional political channels and social movements.
title: Comparative Minority Politics

description: Examines politics of African Americans in order to gain a broader perspective of the American political process. Major developments in African American politics (including the civil rights movement, Black presidential bids), continuing problem of racism, responsiveness of key governing institutions.
title: African American Politics

description: Does the Congress do a good job of representing the American citizenry? Is it the most appropriate mechanism for the creation, resolution, and implementation of public policy.
title: The United States Congress

description: Analyzes the Constitution, its amendments, and periods of Constitutional reform as a foundation for a critical evaluation of the Constitution with an eye both to necessary reforms and to elements of the Constitution that should be maintained.
title: Constitutional Convention

description: Examines selected immigration policy debates since the nineteenth century, rationale and consequences of immigration law since 1965, problems of administration, implementation and enforcement, impact of immigration policy on foreign relations, and contemporary debate regarding the future of U.S. policy.
title: U

description: Examines economic limits of cities and welfare policy. Addresses such issues as why are the poor concentrated in the central cities? Which anti-poverty programs will work best in cities? Which level of government can best combat poverty in the U.S.
title: Urban Politics and Policy

description: Examines animal rights/welfare movement’s efforts to transform moral, practical, and legal standing of nonhuman animals in contemporary U.S. Explores intersection of racism, sexism, and speciesism informed by theories of race and ethnicity, including Asian American Studies.
title: Politics of Animal Rights

description: Politics has become divisive and ideological. But ideologies are poorly understood and have become mere labels for identifying friends and enemies. Course analyzes the nature of ideology, focusing on liberalism, conservatism, fascism, socialism, and contemporary "liberation" ideologies.
prerequisites: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
title: Political Ideologies: The Way We View Our World

description: Examination of how psychological theory and research may be used to better understand political thought and behavior. Drawing on theories of learning, cognition, and personality, discusses such topics as the formation of political attitudes, and the process of political decision-making.
title: Political Psychology

description: Studies in selected areas of American politics and society. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Special Topics in American Politics and Society

description: Introduction to game theory and a survey of its political applications. Examples of topics covered include voting in small committees, legislatures, and mass elections; interest group activities and environmental issues; institutional design, and the evolution of cooperative behavior.
title: Game Theory and Politics I

description: More advanced game theory and its political applications, beginning where Game Theory and Politics I ends.  Examples of topics covered include revolutions; arms race; spatial models of party competition; political manipulation; political coalitions and their power.
title: Game Theory and Politics II

description: Examines major thinkers and intellectual movements in the political thought of the 17th and 18th centuries.
title: Modern Political Theory

description: Examines major thinkers and intellectual movements in the political thought of the 20th Century.
title: Twentieth Century Political Theory

description: Focus is on recent major work in social and political theory. An in-depth analysis of a relatively small body of writing. Authors discussed include Jurgen Habermas, Anthony Giddens, and Richard Rorty.
title: Social and Political Theory

description: Examines the ideals, social forces, and historical events that gave rise to liberal political theory. Topics include patriarchal authority, the divine right of kings, religious toleration, slavery, colonialism, political economy, the evolution of law, and tensions between liberty and equality.
title: Origins of Liberalism

description: Examines the evolution of the doctrine of the just war across the history of Western political thought, the importance of changes in the doctrine and whether it applies today; examines international relations case studies to determine today's relevancy.
title: Just War Revisited

description: Examines critically the notion of the "other" by looking at the philosophical challenges difference poses in the context of the European discovery of the New World. Seeks to understand the naissance of the concept of human rights and tolerance.
title: Cannibals and Conquistadores: The Philosophy of the Other

description: Examines critically the notion of the "other" by looking at the philosophical challenges difference poses in the context of the European discovery of the New World. Seeks to understand the naissance of the concept of human rights and tolerance.
prerequisites: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
title: Cannibals and Conquistadores: The Philosophy of the Other

description: Political representation plays an important role in democratic systems, but is elusive once examined closely.  Students delve into the concept and relate different views to political life. Half of the course is spent on writing instruction.
prerequisites: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
title: Types of Political Representation

description: Introduces major theories and classic texts in ethics, from Plato and Aristotelian virtue ethics to utilitarianism and Kant and contemporary moral psychology.
title: The Moral of the Story: Introductory Seminar in Ethics

description: Focuses on how we learn about ethics from stories, in the form of fables, bedtime stories, religious stories, soap operas, television, and movies as adults. Students bring in stories that informed their own ethical development.
prerequisites: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
title: Moral of the Story: Introduction to Ethics

description: Examines differences traditionally judged politically salient—race, ethnicity, religion, gender. Personal interviews with an elderly person encourage students to understand the social construction of difference and to reexamine their own attitudes by putting themselves in the place of another.
prerequisites: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
title: Ethics of Difference

description: Can people keep their humanity during war? What does the term humanity signify when simply surviving requires faith, courage, and desperation? When facing wartime brutality, must we abrogate morality? What does it mean to compose a moral life during war?.
prerequisites: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
title: The Moral Life During War

description: Studies in selected areas of political theory and methods. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
title: Special Topics in Political Theory and Methods

description: Examination of problems in global political-economic relations through competing conceptual lenses or grand theories: mercantilism, liberalism, and Marxism. Surveys North-North and North-South issues relating power and wealth.
title: International Political Economy

description: Integration of theoretical perspectives in international political economy with the study of economic development in East Asia, with special emphasis on regional integration.
title: International Political Economy of East Asia

description: U.S. policy toward the countries of East Asia: bilateral and regional security relationships, U.S. economic relations with the major Asian countries, the development of regional institutions, and human rights.
title: U
